In one of the more sudden
outbreaks of illness in recent
years at Hopkins, students
complaining of a variety of
"flu-like" ills began streaming
into the Health Clinic on Monday afternoon, prompting a
Baltimore Health Department
investigation of the freshman
dormitory cafeteria and
widespread speculation of
possible food contamination.
According to Andrea Perry,
director of the Office of
Residential Life, at least sixty
students, mostly freshmen,
have reported to the clinic since
Monday afternoon and the
number is rising.
Nevertheless, pending the
results of extensive lab work
which is underway now, health
experts from Hopkins and the
Baltimore City Health Depart-

ment, are tentatively treating
the wave of illness as a sudden
outbreak of viral infections
rather than food poisoning.
Marilyn Gall, the Administrative Nurse Practitioner of the
Health Clinic explains that,
"So far, we've found no correlation between something
students ate and their illnesses.
In fact, a lot of the sick students
who have come to the clinic are
upperclassmen who don't eat at
the cafeteria or freshmen who
didn't eat there at the beginning of the week. So we think
that the illnesses stem more
likely from viral infections than
food contamination."
Officials from the City
Health Department who inspected the cafeteria and passed out questionnaires to
students seemed to agree with
Gall, saying to Dan Miller,
director of Food Service at the

Terrace Room, that the
cafeteria is "one of the cleanest
around."
The Health Department Inspectors took samples of ARA
food including one of the 625
steak sandwiches served for
lunch on Monday which has
been popularly suspected as being one of the more likely
causes of the rash of illness.
The results of the testing,
however, will not be available
for some time, according to
Gall.

ARA at Hopkins, was out of
town yesterday at the time of a
pre-scheduled interview with
the News-Letter and was,
therefore, unavailable for comment. But Dan Miller, the

Debate Tourney to be Held
Here Today and Tomorrow
by Adil Al-Shabkhoun
This weekend, over thirty
two-person teams from eleven
colleges will,debate the topic,
"Spock Around the Clock," in
the 32nd Annual Johns
Hopkins Debate Tournament
to be held in Levering Hall. The
Hopkins tournament, with
teams invited from Princeton,
Goucher, University of
Maryland, Boston University,
University of Pennsylvania,
Rhode Island College, Columbia, Swarthmore, Navy,
Georgetown, and Haverford, is
the largest southern parliamentary debate tournament in the
nation.
"The tournament's topic will
give the teams a choice between
two topics, one from 'Star
Trek' and one from the
1950's," stated Steve Levine,
third-year president of the

Debate Council.
"Parliamentary debate differs from formal debate in that
it requires no work, but lots of
practice," noted Levine. A
topic is given and the twomember team has ten minutes
to think about it before
debating. "It's fun and there's
no preparation involved. It's
just what comes off," Levine
stated.
Much of the stuffiness
associated with normal debate
is not present in the parliamentary form, according to Levine.
"Heckling is permitted and in
the final round of a tournament, everyone heckles. It's a
total mess.
"We have over thirty individuals on the team and that
includes
about
twenty
freshmen, which is the largest
number of active freshmen on
any active team," said Levine.

"With this, the second year that
we've been doing parliamentary
debate, we have become the
fastest-growing team on our
circuit."
The Hopkins Debate Council is also the top team in the
circuit, according to Levine.
"One of our teams competed at
Fordham last year and took second place of the 96 teams that
represented 40 colleges. This
year we're sending a team to
Montreal to compete in the
World Championships, and we
have four teams that have
qualified to compete in the National Championships of
American
Parliamentary
Debate on April 12 and 13 at
Colgate University.
"Most schools just send one
team. We're sending four,
which is presently the most
from any American school,"
Levine stated.

scholars spoke at a symposium
sponsored by Hopkins, the
Renaissance Institute of
Florence, and the University of
Florence. Because it was held in
the Strozzi palace, the subject
of his first book-length study of
the Florentine construction industry, the symposium marked
a significant point in his career.
Despite receiving several
other academic honors and
fellowships in the past (The
Building of Renaissance
Florence received the Howard
R. Marraro prize in 1981), he
was nonetheless surprised by
Italy's decision to knight him.
He is presently director of the
Spellman Villa, the Hopkins
center in Florence, and was unsure when he left Homewood
exactly what type of ceremony
would
accompany
the
presentation.
It was only four months after

the Republic of Italy knighted
Goldthwaite that Baldwin was
created a chevalier of the Order
of Arts and Letters by the
Republic of France. Although
he, too, had received numerous
academic awards and honors
(among them a Fulbright
Fellowship, two Guggenheim
Fellowships, and a National
Endowment for the Humanities
Fellowship), he was just as
pleasantly surprised by the
French as Goldthwaite had
been by the Italians.
Perhaps it seems somewhat
strange that someone can still
be created either a knight of
Italy or a chevalier of France,
but the concept of knighthood
and the title of knight have
been kept alive in recent French
and Italian history. In France,
.particularly, knighthood has
been prescient in the French national conscience. In 1963,
Prime Minister De Gaulle
responded to what he felt was

a lessening of the stature of the
Legion of Honor by creating a
separate Order of Arts and Letters. He reserved the induction
into the Legion of Honor for
those select few who were a
significant aid and example to
the French nation and people.
It is to this Order of Arts and
Letters that Baldwin, a
specialist in medieval French
history, has been inducted. His
published works include City
on the Seine: Paris under Louis
IX, 1226-1270(1975); Masters,
Princes, and Merchants: The
Social Views of Peter the
Chanter and his Circle (1970);
The Scholastic Culture of the
Middle Ages(1971); and, to be
published this year, The
Government
of Philip
Augustus: Foundation of
French Royal Power in the
Middle Ages. Last February, he
delivered a series of lectures on
Philip Augustus at the College
de France in Paris.

Among the many awards in
the world of academia, there
are few which carry the distinction of these two. Certainly
most members of the faculty at
Hopkins have vitae brimming
with marks of honor and excellence in scholarship. Nevertheless, few indeed are the ones
which hold so many traditional
associations. Several other
similar honors which have been
bestowed on Hopkins faculty
include the Order of Commendatori
allmerits
della
Republica, given to Professor
Charles Singleton in 1958; the
Dante medal(one of only three
ever given, the other recipients
being T.S. Eliot and Andre
Pezard) given to Professor
Singleton by the Italian government in the same year; the Ordine del Cherubino, given to
Professor Clifford Truesdell in
1978;

oBrad Marks reported on the
Public Interest Investment Advisory Committee (PIIAC).

Marks represents the Council
on the committee, which advises the university on how it
should vote on resolutions
which come before stockholders of companies in which
the university owns stock.
The resolutions, which often
address topics such as company
investment in South Africa and
nuclear weapons, are discussed
by the representatives of all
divisions of the university in
PIIAC. Resolutions approved
by PIIAC come before the
Board of Trustees' Committee
on Investment, which approves
roughly fifty percent of them.
It is important how the university votes, said Marks, because
the votes of even a small
percentage of stockholders can
affect the policies of
corporations.

"As students and as a university, we have a concern about
how investments are used," he
said.

the space could not be shared

and get lots of sleep and a well
balanced diet."

one of the more sudden outbreaks of viral infections at

An Invasion of Privacy
Undergraduates at the Johns Hopkins
University are constantly reminded by the
administration here that they are expected
to conduct themselves as adults and to take
responsibility for their actions in such diverse
spheres as social life and academic concentration. However, a recent development indicates that we, as students, are perhaps not
entitled to all the privileges that such supposed maturity would suggest. Specifically,
our right to privacy is not as secure as we
might assume.
Within the last week, an electronic letter,
written by an undergraduate and intended
confidentially, was brought to the attention
of the Director of Homewood Computing
Services David Binko. The letter was
discovered to contain perjorative references
to Binko, who subsequently sent a vicious
letter to the author threatening retaliation.
That Binko used his position and the University computer system for his own vindictive
ends is reprehensible and should be seriously questioned.
Binko cannot be blamed for reading the
letter; it was incorrectly addressed and it is
policy to check the file under these circumstances. However, the fact that he wrote
a letter in response is questionable and does
not demonstrate a great deal of forethought.
Yet even this action is pardonable, given the

content of the letter, but the notion that the
letter was used to threaten the author is
indefensible.
Binko claims that the letter was not intended to threaten, though the text would
suggest otherwise. Binko indicates that he
may take actions "to limit (the author's)
communications to the outside world" by
cancelling the student's computer account.
Such implication is childish and
irresponsible.
The Student Council, upon learning of
these events, passed a resolution Wednesday
night stating that electronic COT respondence
and student computer files be kept confidential and that the Council considers "any unnecessary intrusion by computer system officials into the accounts intolerable."
Council has the right idea, but the
representatives advocate far too little. It must
be made undeniably clear in the future that
the Homewood computer system is not to
be used for personal ends by computer officials. A public reprimand of the Director
should be issued by the Homewood deans.
A formal apology to the involved student
should be forwarded. Finally, undergraduates should be officially assured of
their right to privacy since it appears that little can be taken for granted at this
institution.

The Second Term
by Jeff Horn
Ronald Reagan is an extremely popular man. He was
recently reelected by a vast
margin and enjoys a long-term
approval rating unmatched by
any recent president. Yet, much
of his popularity is personal,
not based on his political positions. These positions individually and collectively make
one wonder about his
possibilities for success on the
issues during the second term.
Let's begin with the balanced budget amendment. Reagan
has continually supported such
an amendment, but he has
never submitted a budget to
Congress with less than a $150
billion dollar deficit. As a matter of fact, deficits have doubled under Reagan. Thus,
Reagan's advocacy of a balanced budget amendment can only be seen as wishful thinking.
Reagan has also consistently
endorsed a military buildup for
a "strong" defense. Therefore,
the military budget has increased dramatically since Reagan
took office. Few would• argue
with Reagan's motives or intentions, but the buildup's scope
and relative size have been
questioned. Does it make sense
to spend $30 billion on the MX
missile, when Congress and the
military entertain very serious
and substantial doubts about
the vulnerability of the missile?
The President defends the
system as a "bargaining chip"
and wishes to see it continued
because cancellation of the program would send the wrong
"signals" to Moscow about
U.S. "toughness." Is such a
dubious explanation worth $30
billion? Other reasons have
been forwarded, but none by
the President himself. Congress
disagrees with the President on
this issue. Even Senator Barry
Goldwater of Arizona, a
hawkish conservative, has
stated that the MX has little
chance of passing (Time,
1-28-85, p. 22). Reagan,
however, still counts the MX as
an important part of his overall

military program.
Defense spending is also tied
in with the deficit. The high rate
of spending is a major factor in
the deficit's increase. Reagan
has accepted as gospel the insignificant reductions in the
military budget proposed by
Caspar Weinberger. Reagan
seems to feel that this savings is
more than enough. No
weapons system was touched,
nor was military pay. Yet,
Reagan has imposed a reduction of 5% on federal
employees' salaries and is omitting the usual COLA increase.
If Reagan feels that this is
necessary to reduce the deficit,
how can the military budget be
left essentially untouched when
so many other programs like
funds for education and health
care are being slashed to the
bone. Even though the military
is well known for procurement
inefficiency ($4000 dollar coffeemakers)and waste as well as
weapons that are too delicate or
complicated. This question has
been left generally unanswered
by Reagan. Other Republicans,
however, say that the military
will have to shoulder a larger
part of the deficit reduction or
the new budget will not pass
either the Senate or the House.
Thus, another of Reagan's platforms is in trouble.
The President, in a recent
radio interview, stated that
blacks voted against him
because they misunderstood his
policies and exactly how much
he has done for them. One of
the statistics he used was that of
the six million people who
found jobs in the last four
years, one million of them were
black (New York Times,
1-27-85, p. Al2). Another
statistic used in the interview is
the fact that black unemployment is 2½ times white
unemployment. Blacks make
up nearly thirty percent of the
total unemployed, yet they
receive only sixteen percent of
the new jobs. Thus, black
unemployment vis-a-vis whites
is becoming worse, not better as
the President implies. During

by Miriam Tucker
Experts from around the
world met in Tokyo last year at
the International Symposium
on Childhood Diabetes to
discuss the latest findings in the
field of diabetes research. Dr.
Allan Drash, head of the
Department of Endocrinology
at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, was one of the participants. Drash is the immediate past president of the
American Diabetes Association, and one of the world's
leading experts .in the field of

Elimination of these complications is the basis of the many
research efforts going on
around the world. Since virtually all victims of diabetes under
the age of 20 are insulindependent, much research is
directed at these young people,
who stand the greatest chance
developing

CAUSE
The first 'C' is cause, or

American Diabetes Association

Dr. Allan Drash of the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.

Drash summarizes the many
different aspects of diabetes
research in terms of the "five
C's": cause, course, care, complications, and cure. These five
headings encompass most of
the current issues involving the
disorder.
Diabetes mellitus results
when the beta cells of the pancreas slow down or stop producing insulin, the hormone
which allows the body to
metabolize carbohydrates.
The milder form of the
disorder, known as Type II
diabetes, is thought to occur
when the patient's body cells
are resistant to the insulin produced by the pancreas, or when
the pancreas itself produces a
low amount of insulin. Found
mostly in older adults, its control can usually be achieved by
pills or diet alone.
In insulin-dependent diabetes
mellitus(IDDM), however, the
pancreas completely stops producing the hormone and the patient must rely on daily injections of insulin to stay alive.
Although these injections do
keep the patient alive, in no
way can they be considered a
cure. Diabetics often experience
higher than normal levels of
blood sugar. They are also subject to spells of low blood sugar
known as insulin reactions,
which can cause brain damage
or death if not treated with
sugar immediately.
Many long-term complications, such as kidney damage,
atherosclerosis, eye damage,
and neuropathy can also occur

is particularly aimed at determining the factors involved in
beta cell damage. Although little is known for sure, it is
generally, believed that genetic
predisposition, viral infections,
and autoimmune destruction of
beta cells interact with environmental factors to cause
diabetes.
One interesting finding is
that a certain gene involved in
the immune system, the HLADR, is of two particular types
in diabetics. Almost all IDDM
patients possess either HLADR 3, HLA-DR 4, or both.
This would obviously suggest
genetic predisposition to the
disorder. Furthermore, it seems
that the two types of genes
themselves differ in the
underlying etiology and clinical
course of the patient's diabetes.
While HLA-DR 3 is associated
with a chronic, ongoing,
autoimmune process, HLA-DR
4 patients are more likely to
develop diabetes by an acute infectious process. This provides
evidence
that
genetic
predisposition may interact
with autoimmune, viral, or environmental factors in the
destruction of beta cells.
Many specific viruses have
been implicated in relation to
diabetes, including the coxsackie group, mumps, rubella,
influenza, and hepatitis. In
1973, during an epidemic of
Reye's Syndrome which occurred across the northeastern.
United States, five out of twenty afflicted children who died at
Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh also presented symptoms
of diabetes mellitus. It was later
discovered that the primary initiating virus for Reye's Syndrome was Influenza B, thus
suggesting a link between this
virus and diabetes.

Environmental factors are
also implicated in the causation
of diabetes. Certain pollutants
and toxins have been shown to
cause the disorder in laboratory
animals. Several individuals
became diabetic after attempting suicide by ingesting vacor,
a type of rat poison. Some
nitrosamines in food have also
been implicated in beta-cell
damage.
Another interesting finding is
the enormous variation in expression of IDDM around the
world. The highest attack rate
is in Finland, where 40 cases occur for every 100,000 children
each year. In Pittsburgh, the
rate is 15 per 100,000, while in
Japan, less than 1 case per
100,000 occurs each year. These
differences can't be explained
by genetic factors alone; the
primary explanation must lie in
the environment.
One difference in the various
countries is in the mode of
nutrition. Animal studies have
shown that dietary manipulation has a large impact on the
expression of diabetes. A study
in Copenhagen found that
breast-feeding may have a protective mechanism against
diabetes, or that absence of
breast-feeding may lead to increased susceptibility in individuals who already have the
underlying defect. Evidence for
this includes the fact that the
frequency of IDDM increases
the further a population is from
the equator. This corresponds
to the increase in industrialized
areas, which, in turn, means a
decrease in the tendency of
mothers in a population to
breast-feed. In Samoa, where
there are no cows, all children
are breast-fed. There are no

IDDM victims in Samoa. When
Samoans move to another
country, however, future
generations begin to develop
diabetes at a rate equivalent to
the rate in that country.

by Anne Jackley
One year ago, the Reproductive Rights Alliance of the
Feminist Alliance began doing
clinic defense at the Howard
Street Planned Parenthood.
Clinic defense is exactly what
the term implies: defending a
clinic from anti-abortion activists. Although this may encompass a wide range of activities, the Reproductive
Rights Alliance focuses mainly
on client escorting.
After last year's 11th anniversary of the Roe versus
Wade Supreme Court decision
which legalized abortion, during which anti-choice protests
received a large amount of
media coverage, members of
the Reproductive Rights
Alliance approached the
clinic's
Street
Howard
Volunteer Coordinator to offer
their services. The clinic gets
picketed every Saturday morning, and demonstrators were
beginning to get more aggressive towards patients, so
Planned Parenthood accepted
the offer of escorts.
Since then, the Reproductive
Rights Alliance has grown in
numbers and in strength. Every
Saturday morning between five
and ten people pull themselves
out of bed at 7:00 a.m. and go

down to Howard Street,
weather,
of
regardless
temperature, or hangovers.
Another half-dozen are "oncall" in case reinforcements are
needed for an unexpected
demonstration or above
average levels of harassment.
Once they arrive at the clinic,
they meet with the staff coordinator to receive their escort
signs and identification badges,
and any special information
they may need to know that
day. Their primary responsibility is to insure that those women
and men who have legitimate
reason are able to enter the
clinic, and to make sure that
those efforts do not escalate the
level of protester activity.
The protesters arrive around
8:00 a.m. Anywhere from 5 or
6 to as many as 50 protesters
will begin walking up and down
on the sidewalk. By order of the
Baltimore City Police Department, they must keep moving;
although this rule is rarely
followed strictly, most do walk
about.
Some of the protesters content themselves to actual
picketing: carrying signs and
the like. Others pass out
literature and do "sidewalk
"Sidewalk
counseling."
counseling" usually means accosting a patient halfway down

the sidewalk, shoving some
gory pictures into their face,
asking them repeatedly whether
or not they are going to have an
abortion, and, if they continue
to ignore the protester, screaming after their receding figure in.
the doorway, "Murderer!
Murderer!"
The job of the escort is to
help clients enter the building
with a minimum of emotional
assault, providing a distraction
for the attentions of the protesters; and doing anything
possible to make the whole
scene easier for the clients. This
entails stating clearly to the patients "I am with the clinic. I'll
escort you into the clinic if you
like" so that clients do not confuse who is who on the
sidewalk. It entails keeping
one's temper, even when protesters harass you; it means not
responding to comments about
your morals, your mother, your
clothing, religion, and/or
lifestyle. It means being willing
to deflect attention and abuse
so that someone can safely
enter the clinic. It means not
touching protesters; any contact should be accidental or, if
serious, in self-defense. Protesters have been known to
deliberately press assault
charges as an intentional tactic

shown in those short flashes are
in the movie but only as short
flashes at the movie's beginning, and break-dancing is present only in a very short segment at the start of the film.
Nevertheless, in terms of
entertainment, That's Dancing!
is hard to beat. Note well: if
you want to see this movie,
don't wait until it comes to
Cable or VHS—this movie is at
its greatest on the big screen.

furnished with an expanded

additions include a squat bar,
a military bench, and a curl
bench. Previously free weights

In one of the more sudden
outbreaks of illness in recent
years at Hopkins, students
complaining of a variety of
"flu-like" ills began streaming
into the Health Clinic on Monday afternoon, prompting a
Baltimore Health Department
investigation of the freshman
dormitory cafeteria and
widespread speculation of
possible food contamination.
According to Andrea Perry,
director of the Office of
Residential Life, at least sixty
students, mostly freshmen,
have reported to the clinic since
Monday afternoon and the
number is rising.
Nevertheless, pending the
results of extensive lab work
which is underway now, health
experts from Hopkins and the
Baltimore City Health Depart-

ment, are tentatively treating
the wave of illness as a sudden
outbreak of viral infections
rather than food poisoning.
Marilyn Gall, the Administrative Nurse Practitioner of the
Health Clinic explains that,
"So far, we've found no correlation between something
students ate and their illnesses.
In fact, a lot of the sick students
who have come to the clinic are
upperclassmen who don't eat at
the cafeteria or freshmen who
didn't eat there at the beginning of the week. So we think

our right to privacy is not as secure as we
might assume.

written by an undergraduate and intended
confidentially, was brought to the attention
of the Director of Homewood Computing
Services David Binko. The letter was
discovered to contain perjorative references
to Binko, who subsequently sent a vicious
letter to the author threatening retaliation.
That Binko used his position and the University computer system for his own vindictive
ends is reprehensible and should be seriously questioned.
Binko cannot be blamed for reading the
letter; it was incorrectly addressed and it is
policy to check the file under these circumstances. However, the fact that he wrote
a letter in response is questionable and does
not demonstrate a great deal of forethought.
Yet even this action is pardonable, given the

content of the letter, but the notion that the
letter was used to threaten the author is
indefensible.
Binko claims that the letter was not intended to threaten, though the text would
suggest otherwise. Binko indicates that he
may take actions "to limit (the author's)
communications to the outside world" by
cancelling the student's computer account.
Such implication is childish and
irresponsible.
The Student Council, upon learning of
these events, passed a resolution Wednesday
night stating that electronic COT respondence
and student computer files be kept confidential and that the Council considers "any unnecessary intrusion by computer system officials into the accounts intolerable."
Council has the right idea, but the
representatives advocate far too little. It must
be made undeniably clear in the future that
the Homewood computer system is not to
be used for personal ends by computer officials. A public reprimand of the Director
should be issued by the Homewood deans.
A formal apology to the involved student
should be forwarded. Finally, undergraduates should be officially assured of
their right to privacy since it appears that little can be taken for granted at this
institution.

The Second Term
by Jeff Horn
Ronald Reagan is an extremely popular man. He was
recently reelected by a vast
margin and enjoys a long-term
approval rating unmatched by
any recent president. Yet, much
of his popularity is personal,
not based on his political positions. These positions individually and collectively make
one wonder about his
possibilities for success on the
issues during the second term.
Let's begin with the balanced budget amendment. Reagan
has continually supported such
an amendment, but he has
never submitted a budget to
Congress with less than a $150
billion dollar deficit. As a matter of fact, deficits have doubled under Reagan. Thus,
Reagan's advocacy of a balanced budget amendment can only be seen as wishful thinking.
Reagan has also consistently
endorsed a military buildup for
a "strong" defense. Therefore,
the military budget has increased dramatically since Reagan
took office. Few would• argue
with Reagan's motives or intentions, but the buildup's scope
and relative size have been
questioned. Does it make sense
to spend $30 billion on the MX
missile, when Congress and the
military entertain very serious
and substantial doubts about
the vulnerability of the missile?
The President defends the
system as a "bargaining chip"
and wishes to see it continued
because cancellation of the program would send the wrong
"signals" to Moscow about
U.S. "toughness." Is such a
dubious explanation worth $30
billion? Other reasons have
been forwarded, but none by
the President himself. Congress
disagrees with the President on
this issue. Even Senator Barry
Goldwater of Arizona, a
hawkish conservative, has
stated that the MX has little
chance of passing (Time,
1-28-85, p. 22). Reagan,
however, still counts the MX as
an important part of his overall

military program.
Defense spending is also tied
in with the deficit. The high rate
of spending is a major factor in
the deficit's increase. Reagan
has accepted as gospel the insignificant reductions in the
military budget proposed by
Caspar Weinberger. Reagan
seems to feel that this savings is
more than enough. No
weapons system was touched,
nor was military pay. Yet,
Reagan has imposed a reduction of 5% on federal
employees' salaries and is omitting the usual COLA increase.
If Reagan feels that this is
necessary to reduce the deficit,
how can the military budget be
left essentially untouched when
so many other programs like
funds for education and health
care are being slashed to the
bone. Even though the military
is well known for procurement
inefficiency ($4000 dollar coffeemakers)and waste as well as
weapons that are too delicate or
complicated. This question has
been left generally unanswered
by Reagan. Other Republicans,
however, say that the military
will have to shoulder a larger
part of the deficit reduction or
the new budget will not pass
either the Senate or the House.
Thus, another of Reagan's platforms is in trouble.
The President, in a recent
radio interview, stated that
blacks voted against him
because they misunderstood his
policies and exactly how much
he has done for them. One of
the statistics he used was that of
the six million people who
found jobs in the last four
years, one million of them were
black (New York Times,
1-27-85, p. Al2). Another
statistic used in the interview is
the fact that black unemployment is 2½ times white
unemployment. Blacks make
up nearly thirty percent of the
total unemployed, yet they
receive only sixteen percent of
the new jobs. Thus, black
unemployment vis-a-vis whites
is becoming worse, not better as
the President implies. During

Researchers Aim for Better Treatment of Diabetes
by Miriam Tucker
Experts from around the
world met in Tokyo last year at
the International Symposium
on Childhood Diabetes to
discuss the latest findings in the
field of diabetes research. Dr.
Allan Drash, head of the
Department of Endocrinology
at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, was one of the participants. Drash is the immediate past president of the
American Diabetes Association, and one of the world's
leading experts .in the field of

Elimination of these complications is the basis of the many
research efforts going on
around the world. Since virtually all victims of diabetes under
the age of 20 are insulindependent, much research is
directed at these young people,
who stand the greatest chance
developing
future
of

CAUSE
The first 'C' is cause, or
etiology of diabetes. Research

American Diabetes Association

Dr. Allan Drash of the Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh.

childhood diabetes.
Drash summarizes the many
different aspects of diabetes
research in terms of the "five
C's": cause, course, care, complications, and cure. These five
headings encompass most of
the current issues involving the
disorder.
Diabetes mellitus results
when the beta cells of the pancreas slow down or stop producing insulin, the hormone
which allows the body to
metabolize carbohydrates.
The milder form of the
disorder, known as Type II
diabetes, is thought to occur
when the patient's body cells
are resistant to the insulin produced by the pancreas, or when
the pancreas itself produces a
low amount of insulin. Found
mostly in older adults, its control can usually be achieved by
pills or diet alone.
In insulin-dependent diabetes
mellitus(IDDM), however, the
pancreas completely stops producing the hormone and the patient must rely on daily injections of insulin to stay alive.
Although these injections do
keep the patient alive, in no
way can they be considered a
cure. Diabetics often experience
higher than normal levels of
blood sugar. They are also subject to spells of low blood sugar
known as insulin reactions,
which can cause brain damage
or death if not treated with
sugar immediately.
Many long-term complications, such as kidney damage,
atherosclerosis, eye damage,
and neuropathy can also occur

is particularly aimed at determining the factors involved in
beta cell damage. Although little is known for sure, it is
generally, believed that genetic
predisposition, viral infections,
and autoimmune destruction of
beta cells interact with environmental factors to cause
diabetes.
One interesting finding is
that a certain gene involved in
the immune system, the HLADR, is of two particular types
in diabetics. Almost all IDDM
patients possess either HLADR 3, HLA-DR 4, or both.
This would obviously suggest
genetic predisposition to the
disorder. Furthermore, it seems
that the two types of genes
themselves differ in the
underlying etiology and clinical
course of the patient's diabetes.
While HLA-DR 3 is associated
with a chronic, ongoing,
autoimmune process, HLA-DR
4 patients are more likely to
develop diabetes by an acute infectious process. This provides
evidence
that
genetic
predisposition may interact
with autoimmune, viral, or environmental factors in the
destruction of beta cells.
Many specific viruses have
been implicated in relation to
diabetes, including the coxsackie group, mumps, rubella,
influenza, and hepatitis. In
1973, during an epidemic of
Reye's Syndrome which occurred across the northeastern.
United States, five out of twenty afflicted children who died at
Children's Hospital in Pittsburgh also presented symptoms
of diabetes mellitus. It was later
discovered that the primary initiating virus for Reye's Syndrome was Influenza B, thus
suggesting a link between this
virus and diabetes.

Environmental factors are
also implicated in the causation
of diabetes. Certain pollutants
and toxins have been shown to
cause the disorder in laboratory
animals. Several individuals
became diabetic after attempting suicide by ingesting vacor,
a type of rat poison. Some
nitrosamines in food have also
been implicated in beta-cell
damage.
Another interesting finding is
the enormous variation in expression of IDDM around the
world. The highest attack rate
is in Finland, where 40 cases occur for every 100,000 children
each year. In Pittsburgh, the
rate is 15 per 100,000, while in
Japan, less than 1 case per
100,000 occurs each year. These
differences can't be explained
by genetic factors alone; the
primary explanation must lie in
the environment.
One difference in the various
countries is in the mode of
nutrition. Animal studies have
shown that dietary manipulation has a large impact on the
expression of diabetes. A study
in Copenhagen found that
breast-feeding may have a protective mechanism against
diabetes, or that absence of
breast-feeding may lead to increased susceptibility in individuals who already have the
underlying defect. Evidence for
this includes the fact that the
frequency of IDDM increases
the further a population is from
the equator. This corresponds
to the increase in industrialized
areas, which, in turn, means a
decrease in the tendency of
mothers in a population to
breast-feed. In Samoa, where
there are no cows, all children
are breast-fed. There are no

IDDM victims in Samoa. When
Samoans move to another
country, however, future
generations begin to develop
diabetes at a rate equivalent to
the rate in that country.

Students Help Protect Clinic
by Anne Jackley
One year ago, the Reproductive Rights Alliance of the
Feminist Alliance began doing
clinic defense at the Howard
Street Planned Parenthood.
Clinic defense is exactly what
the term implies: defending a
clinic from anti-abortion activists. Although this may encompass a wide range of activities, the Reproductive
Rights Alliance focuses mainly
on client escorting.
After last year's 11th anniversary of the Roe versus
Wade Supreme Court decision
which legalized abortion, during which anti-choice protests
received a large amount of
media coverage, members of
the Reproductive Rights
Alliance approached the
clinic's
Street
Howard
Volunteer Coordinator to offer
their services. The clinic gets
picketed every Saturday morning, and demonstrators were
beginning to get more aggressive towards patients, so
Planned Parenthood accepted
the offer of escorts.
Since then, the Reproductive
Rights Alliance has grown in
numbers and in strength. Every
Saturday morning between five
and ten people pull themselves
out of bed at 7:00 a.m. and go

down to Howard Street,
weather,
of
regardless
temperature, or hangovers.
Another half-dozen are "oncall" in case reinforcements are
needed for an unexpected
demonstration or above
average levels of harassment.
Once they arrive at the clinic,
they meet with the staff coordinator to receive their escort
signs and identification badges,
and any special information
they may need to know that
day. Their primary responsibility is to insure that those women
and men who have legitimate
reason are able to enter the
clinic, and to make sure that
those efforts do not escalate the
level of protester activity.
The protesters arrive around
8:00 a.m. Anywhere from 5 or
6 to as many as 50 protesters
will begin walking up and down
on the sidewalk. By order of the
Baltimore City Police Department, they must keep moving;
although this rule is rarely
followed strictly, most do walk
about.
Some of the protesters content themselves to actual
picketing: carrying signs and
the like. Others pass out
literature and do "sidewalk
"Sidewalk
counseling."
counseling" usually means accosting a patient halfway down

the sidewalk, shoving some
gory pictures into their face,
asking them repeatedly whether
or not they are going to have an
abortion, and, if they continue
to ignore the protester, screaming after their receding figure in.
the doorway, "Murderer!
Murderer!"
The job of the escort is to
help clients enter the building
with a minimum of emotional
assault, providing a distraction
for the attentions of the protesters; and doing anything
possible to make the whole
scene easier for the clients. This
entails stating clearly to the patients "I am with the clinic. I'll
escort you into the clinic if you
like" so that clients do not confuse who is who on the
sidewalk. It entails keeping
one's temper, even when protesters harass you; it means not
responding to comments about
your morals, your mother, your
clothing, religion, and/or
lifestyle. It means being willing
to deflect attention and abuse
so that someone can safely
enter the clinic. It means not
touching protesters; any contact should be accidental or, if
serious, in self-defense. Protesters have been known to
deliberately press assault
charges as an intentional tactic

the past has become something
of a cliche but if That's Dancing! accomplishes anything, it
presents solid evidence for the
validity of this prejudice.
The movie itself is not
flawless—the movie ballet section tends to drag (though I'm
sure all you Peabody dance
people will love it) and the narrative, while informative, is frequently gushy and banal—
every number and every performer, it seems, is "one of the
best" somethings "ever." Furthermore, That's Dancing! is
not the definitive work on
movie dance; Gene Kelly made
a decision not to repeat any
numbers from the That's Entertainment! films and thus such
greats as Gene Kelly's "Singing
in the Rain" dance and Donald

O'Connor's "Make 'Em
Laugh" are missing. Moreover,
the ads for this movie are a bit
deceptive—many of the bits
shown in those short flashes are
in the movie but only as short
flashes at the movie's beginning, and break-dancing is present only in a very short segment at the start of the film.
Nevertheless, in terms of
entertainment, That's Dancing!
is hard to beat. Note well: if
you want to see this movie,
don't wait until it comes to
Cable or VHS—this movie is at
its greatest on the big screen.
The closest it's playing to
Hopkins currently is up at the
York Ridge Shopping Center in
Timonium, but it was advertised at the Rotunda so hopefully
it will eventually get there.

The Hopkins athletic department culminated a year of
diligent research over intersession with the drastic improvement of the general fitness
weight room.

varsity weight room) had

cramped, poorly ventilated

the swimming championships

first class facility."

there's more space vertically as

furnished with an expanded

additions include a squat bar,
a military bench, and a curl
bench. Previously free weights
